div1.p: THE WAY TO GET MARRIED; A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.

p.hi: AUTHOR OF COLUMBUS-ZORINSKI-CHILDREN IN THE WOOD, &

div1.p: LONDON: PRINTED FOR T. N. LONGMAN, PATERNOSTER-ROW.

div1.head: PROLOGUE.
div1.byline: Written by W. T. FITZGERALD, Esquire.

sp.l: THE stage should be, to life, a faithful glass,
Reflecting modes, and manners as they pass;
If these extravagant appear to you,
Blame not the drama,—the reflection's true—
Our Author makes of virtue no parade,
And only ridicules the vice of trade;
Exposes Folly in its native tint,
And leaves, mankind to profit by the hint.
The modern buck,—how diff'rent from the beau
In bag and ruffles, sixty years ago!
The city coxcomb then was seldom seen,
(Consin'd to Bunhill-row, or Bethnal-green:)
West of Cheapside you then could scarcely meet
The gay Lothario—of Threadneedle-street!
His folly rarely met the public eye,
Or, like a shadow, pass'd unheeded by:
Tradesman and rake were then remov'd as far
As gay St James's is from Temple-bar.
But now the cit must breathe a purer air,
The 'Change he visits—lives in Badford-square—
Insures a fleet—then Bootle's club attends,
Proud to be notic'd by his titled friends;
And tries to join, by Dissipation's aid,
The man of fashion with the man of trade.
Vain to associate with superior rank,
He quits his ledger—for the Faro bank;
His dashing curricle down Bond-street drives,
Risking his own—and worse—his horses' lives;
Till, urging Fortune's glowing wheel too fast,
This empty air-blown bubble breaks at last!
Tho' trade may give such upstart mushrooms birth,
The Muse pays homage to its real worth.
This isle to commerce owes her splendid state,
The source of all that makes her truly great!
And 'midst her busy sons enough are found
To raise dejected mis'ry from the ground.
While commerce, with a lib'ral heart bestows
Her wealth, to mitigate the poor man's woes;
Seeks out the wretch, his gloomy prison cheers,
And wipes, with pitying hand, the widow's tears—
The applauding world will say (such bounty giv'n)
The English merchant is the steward of heav'n.
Our Author now that candour would implore,
Which your indulgence has bestow'd before;
Still on a gen'rous Public he depends;
Give your support—he asks no better friends!

div1.head: THE WAY TO GET MARRIED A COMEDY.

div3.head: SCENE I.
div3.stage: A Room in a House—Bells ringing.

sp.speaker: DASHALL
sp.p: LANDLORD!

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: Here I am—noisy chap this.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Where are all your people? Damn it, Landlord, is this your attention?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Who do you damn, eh? If you don't like my house, march,—there's another in the town.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: This rascal now, because he has the best beds and wine on the road, claims the privilege of insulting his guests—call my servants up.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Not I—enough plague with my own—why don't you go to the other inn? I'll tell you—because you know when you are well off, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Impudent scoundrel! but as I want information, I must humour him.—You're a high fellow.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: An't I?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p:
And so, old Boar's head, my good friend, To by Allspice, by the sudden death of his predecessor,
enters this day upon the tonish office of sheriff of your ancient corporarion.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: He does.—And what's better, by the sudden death of an old maid, miss Sarah Sapless, he and his daughter will, it is said, enter upon the fingering of about thirty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Good news, egad!—Well, old Porcupine, get dinner; and, d'ye hear, none of your ropy champagne—the real stuff (slaps him on the back.)

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Well, I will—Ecod, I like you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Come, be off (strikes him with his whip.)

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Ecod, you have an agreeable way with you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: In the ticklish state of my circumstances, Allspice and his daughter will be worth attending to.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Letters, sir, from London.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Now for it! this makes me a bankrupt, or a good man. (Reads) Dear Dashall, all's up—As I thought.—Transfer swears if you don't settle your bear account in a week, he'll black-board you—Pleasant enough!—Affectionate inquiries are making after you at Lloyd's; and, to crown all, Hops were so lively last market, that there is already a lose of thousands upon that scheme—Nothing can save you but the ready.—Yours, TIM. TICK.

N. B. Green peas were yesterday sold at Leadenhall-Market at nine-pence a peck; so your bet of three thousand pounds on that event is lost. So! lurch'd every way—stocks, insurance, hops, hazard,
and green peas, all over the left shoulder; and then, like a flat, I must get pigeon'd at faro by ladies of quality; for the swagger of saying The duchess and I were curst jolly last night; but, confusion to despair! I'm no flincher.—If I can but humbug old Allspice out of a few thousands, and marry his daughter, I shall cut a gay figure, and make a splash yet.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: A room for Lady Sorrel.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What the devil brings her here?—Old and ugly as she is, I'll take decent odds but 'tis an intrigue.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Inform my cousin Caustic, I'm here.— Ah! Dashall, I suppose the warm weather has driven you from town.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: True; London was certainly too hot for me; but how could your ladyship leave the fascination of play?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Hush! that's not my rural character.—I always assimilate.—The fact is, Dick, I have here a strange, plain-spoken, worthy, and wealthy relation; he gives me considerable sums to distribute in London to the needy, which I lose in play, to people of fashion; and you'll allow that is giving them to the needy, and fulfilling the worthy donor's intention, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Then you are not here because your favourite, young Tangent, is arrived? eh!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p:
What, Dick, have you found out my attachment there? Well, I confess it: and if my regard be, not, I'll take care, my revenge shall be, gratified;
and 'tis a great consolation that one is nearly as sweet as the other.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: And I'll be equally can did. The miserable fact is, I am completely brozier'd, cut down to a sixpence, and have left town.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Like a skilful engineer, who, having laid his train for the destruction of others, prudently retires daring the blow-up.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: In the next room, do you say? (Enters) Lady Sorrel, I rejoice to see you, and have provided at home for your reception.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Then I'll order my carriage and servants there.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: No; I can depend on your prudence, but not on your servants'—S'death! were any of your fashionable London servants to get footing in my family, I suppose in a week my old housekeeper would give conversationes, a little music, and twopenny faro.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Vastly well.—By no means contemptible.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Cousin, this is Mr. Dashall, one of the first men in the city,—sees the first company, lives in the first style—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: This a merchant of the city of London?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Curse the quiz! Ill throw off a little—Perhaps you've not been in town lately.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: No, sir,

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, the old school quite gone by—I remember, my old gig of a father wore a velvet nightcap in his cornering house—what a vile bore, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And pray, sir, what may you wear in your compting house?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Strike me moral if I've seen it these three months. If you wish to trade in style, and make a splash, you must fancy Cheapside Newmarket, and Lloyd's and the Alley faro tables, for Demoivre has as completely ousted Cocker's Arithmetic with us, as Hoyle has the Complete Housewife with our wives, egad—talk of Brooks's or Newmarket; chicken hazard to the game we play at Lloyd's—monopoly's the word now, old boy; hops, corn, sugar, surs—at all in the ring.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Amazing! sir, your capital must be astonishing to be—at all in the ring

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Capital! an old bugbear—never thought of now—no, paper—discount does it.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Paper!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye; suppose I owe a tradesman, my taylor for instance, two thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: A merchant owe his-taylor two thousand pounds! mercy on us!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I give him my note for double the sum, he discounts it—I touch half in the ready—note comes due—double the sum again—touch half again, and so on to the tune of fifty thousand pounds. If monopolies answer, make all frraight—if not, smash—into the Gazette. Brother merchants say "damn'd fine fellow—lived in style:—only traded beyond his capital. So, certificate's signed—ruin a hundred or two reptiles of retailers, and so begin the war again.—That's the way to make a splash—devilish neat, isn't it?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Pretty well.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: How you stare! you don't know nothing of life, old boy.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Vulgar scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: We are the boys in, the city. Why, there's Sweetwort, the brewer,—don't you know Sweetwort? dines an hour later than any duke in the kingdom— imports his own turtle—dresses turbot by a stopwatch—has house-lamb fed on cream, and pigs on pine-apples—gave a jollification t'other day—Stokehole in the brewhouse—asked a dozen peers—all glad to come—can't live as we do. Who make the splash in Hyde-Park? who fill the pit at the opera who inhabit the squares in the west? why, the knowing ones from the east to be sure.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Not the wife one's from the east, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Who support the fashionable faro tables? oh, how the ducheffes chuckle and rub their hands, when they see one of us!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Duchesses keep gaming tables!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To be sure! how the devil shou'd they live? such a blow-up the other night! you were there, Lady Sorrel!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I at a saro table!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Upon my honour I beg pardon—you see, sir, the duchess was dealing, and Mrs. Swagger was punting. Oh ho! cries Mrs. Swagger, "That was very neatly done"—"What do you mean?" says the duchess—"Only, madam, I saw you slip a card"—"dam'me" says the duchess—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Says the duke.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Says the duchess.

sp.speaker: Coust.
sp.p: No, no! "dam'me," says the duke.

sp.speaker: Dash
sp.p: Psha! the duchess, I tell you. It's her way.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Her way! O Lud!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Where was I? oh, "dam'me," says the duchess, "but you turn out of my house"—"and curle me," cries little miss Swagger, (a sweet amiable little creature of about fourteen) "if we stay here to be swindled."—Words got high, and oaths flew about like rouleaus; but as they had plucked me of my last feather, I got up, and, in imitation of my betters, twang'd off a few dam'mes, and retired.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: The world's at an end—all is sophisticated!—nothing bears even its right name—whoredom is gallantry; swindling, running out; female debauchery, a faux-pas. The murdering duellist has a nice sense of honour, the cuckold-maker is a dear delicious devil, and the cuckold the best humour'd creature in the world.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well said, old one—you've some nous about you.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Foul-tongued blockhead!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tell counsellor Endless I'll be in court presently.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I think I know that voice.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: So do I. (aside)—'Tis your darling nephew, your adopted Tangent—I saw him come out of a chaise with two barristers.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Psha! barristers! you forget he's in the army.

sp.speaker: Lady Ser.
sp.p: May'nt I trust my eyes?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Why, at fifty-nine, cousin, eyes are not always to be trusted. Pray, Mr. Dashall, do you know this nephew of mine?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh yes; but he associates with authors and wits, quite out of our set—we in the city don't vote them gentlemen—you'll never find no wit at my table, I'll take care of that.—But you expect company, and so I'll be off to my friend Allspice's.—By the way, I hear his daughter will touch to the tune of thirty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Caust
sp.p: Very likely: but I don't know any good it will do her.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Not do good! I beg pardon. Riches gives wit,—elegance.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Do they? I'm sorry you're so poor.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Eh! what! oh neat enough! and what do you say riches give, queer one?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Generally, vulgar impertinence.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I congratulate you on being so rich, ha, ha! rat me! but at last I've said a good one. Lady Sorrel, your devoted.—Good bye, queer one!—What a superlative gig it is!

sp.speaker: Caust
sp.p: Was that my nephew's voice?
Sir, your most obedient!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, my dear uncle! who could have expected to have seen you in this part of the world?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
This part of the world! why, 'tis the town
I live in, is it not? and have not you come on purpose to visit me?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: True, uncle; I was—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: At your old tricks, castlebuilding. Fancying yourself Tippoo Saib, I warrant, or empress of all the Russias.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, no, you wrong me—Ah, lady Sorrel, how cou'd you leave town, where you were the ton?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: The ton, ha, ha! Then I suppose grandmothers are the ton?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You have hit it, uncle, (aside to Caustic)—l never saw you look so well.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Dear sir, you slatter.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: He does, he does. Come, sir, no more of that. Age is respectable, and you ought to be above making a jest of an old woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, your behaviour is intolerable. Mr. Tangent, do you dine with us?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nothing can afford me greater felicity—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Than to dine with an old woman—Nonsense! Go home, cousin, go home.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Brute! Mr. Tangent, good morning. Sweet, elegant youth! how my heart doats on him.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Frank, leave that cursed trick, that—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I know what you mean—I believe I used to indulge in little flights of fancy.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: You did indeed.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, that's all over, My life passes in a dull consistent uniformity.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I'm glad on't—Well, how goes on the regiment?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The regiment? Oh, I've left the army. Caust, Oh, you've left the army, (imitating)—and why, sir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I don't know—I imagine I was tired of the routine, field-days, parade, mess-dinners, and so—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And so what, sir?

sp.speaker: Tang
sp.p: I determined to adhere to the law.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I've no patience with your solly. But, sir, are you sure the law has brought you here? Is it not some ridiculous love affair, some jilting tit from Exeter?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll humour his dislike to the sex.— Women. Gewgaws for boys and dotards.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: True. He has a fine understanding.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: What are they all?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Ay; what are they all?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The best of them are virtuously vicious, and impertinently condescending.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: He's a fine youth.—Go on.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: All a contradiction.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: True, Frank; Pope himself says so—
sp.l: "Woman's at best a contradiction still;
sp.p: then he goes on—
sp.l: "A sop their passion, and their prize, a sot."

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: "Alive, ridiculous; and dead, forgot."— Sir, I've the whole epistle by heart.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
Have you? Come to my arms. Now stick
to this and the law, and my whole fortune is your own—when I die.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And in the mean time I'll thank you for a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Thank me! I dare say you will. A thousand pounds! But how is it to be employed?—What fashionable scheme

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: A very unfashionable one; uncle; in paying my debts.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: You know, Frank, you once disgraced yourself, and deeply offended me, by borrowing money of M'Query, a knavish money-lender. If your debts are of that description, you become my antipathy, my detestation.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: On my honour, no.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Well then, as I can better afford to lose it, than an honest creditor, I'll give it you on conditions—first, that you adhere to the law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Granted.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Secondly, that you leave that hair-brain'd folly, which makes me mad,—that castle building.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, granted.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And lastly, that this thousand shall be the sum total of your extravagance.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: With all my heart—And here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: But, Frank, what say you to 30,000l. down on the nail?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I say, sir, that no particular objection to it strikes me at present.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
Then I'll tell you—Here's a will by which it is supposed miss Clementina Allspice will be heiress
to that sum. Now I'll introduce you: and if, on seeing her, you agree with me that she is grossly vulgar, and extravagantly affected,—in short, should you thoroughly dislike her, I can see no rational objection to your marrying her.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Certainly not—I'll attend you; but first I must go to the courts.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Aye, stick to the law—stick to that—stick to any thing. You remember your pranks—This hour writing a satire on the frivolity of the age, the next, riding a hundred miles to shoot at a target —One day drest in solemn black for the purpose of ordination The next in a pink jacket and jockey cap, riding a match at Newmarket—So, no more of that, but stick to the law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: To be sure; what expansion of intellect it occasions! What honours does it not lead to!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Think of the woolsack.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: There's an object to look to!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Tremendous!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: My ambition anticipates my honours, and I see myself in the envied situation.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Dress'd in my robes, I bow to the throne.
sp.stage: (Sits down with dignity in a chair.)

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Zounds! now he's at it.
sp.stage: (Tangent rises and puts on his hat.)
sp.p:
Order! Order! Is it your lordships pleasure this bill
do pass—As many as are content, say, "Aye"—Not content, "No"'—The contents have it.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Now would it not provoke the devil?— I humbly move that your lordship may leave the woolsack, and that your brains may cease to go a woolgathering.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: My lord!—Eh!—Oh!—I beg your excuse, uncle—I was just indulging a little flight.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Yes, I know you were But where are you going?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: To the courts.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Pray stick to the law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And to the woolsack. Does not the hope of that fill our universities with blockheads—and cram our courts full of barristers, with heads as empty as they leave their clients' pockets?—As many as are content, say "Aye" Not content, "No"—The contents have it.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: So mad and absurd as ever! But I trust he has a good heart, and I'll give him fair play; for, sometimes, the subsiding opposition of worth and folly produces the brightest characters, even as the beautiful firmament is said to have been formed from the contending chaos of light and darkness.

div3.head: SCENE II.FAULKNER'S HOUSE—A knocking at the door, Faulkner crosses the stage, and opens the door.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, my master (Mr. Caustic) will wait on you this morning for the payment of his rent.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My compliments, and I shall be glad to see him.

Thank heaven; enough remains for that▪ My rent being paid, perhaps I may gloss over the meagre hue of poverty, till my law-suit is decided. (A barp is brard) Poor Julia! did'st thou know thy father's abject penury, 'twoud break thy heart. Perhaps it may be concealed at least I'll try to think so—Julia! my daughter!
My dearest father!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My child! thou art this day of age.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, sir, (averting her face with dejection, then recovering berself.)—I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Heiress of penury. My darling girl! Oh, had heaven so will'd it, this had been a morning that pleasure might have long'd for. The sad reverse made sleep a stranger to me. I rose, and gave thee, Julia, all a poor fond father could,—a blessing at the throne of mercy.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: More rich, more valued than all the splendour we have lost. Indeed I grieve not for it. Pray, sir, be cheerful, as we are above the reach of want.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Oh! (stisting a groan) True, my love; return to your harp—I expect my attorney—he dispatch'd, I'll come to thee—Sure he stays!—What says my watch?—hold—I forgot I had parted with it

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: How fortunate! Look, sir, I've made a purchase for you (shewing a watch). Since you lost yours, you have been less punctual in coming home, and I have been the loser of many a happy hour—'Tis quite a bargain the man will call to day for die money.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: How unlucky!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: You are not angry? You cannot be! What, not a kiss for my attention?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My only comfort! (kisses her) Here's a bank note—Pay for your purchase, and employ the rest in procuring our household wants. Go in—a thousand blessings on thee.
Poor, luckless wench! Oh, how willingly would I lay down this life, but for thy sake, my child

sp.speaker: M'Query
sp.p: Captain Faulkner!
sp.stage: (Faulkner goes to the door and opens it).

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah, my attorney! Speak, tell me, relieve the sufferings of a parent's heart am I to despair? (M'Query shakes his head) Is there a hope?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Here's a letter.

stage.hi: (Faulkner of opens it with trepidation and gives it to M'Query.)

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Pray read it.

sp.speaker: M'QUERY
sp.p: Sir I am Fau'k. Pray read sorry, that instead of congratulating you " on the recovering your valuable estates, I have to "inform you, that by an unlucky, and accidental "error in our declaration we were non-suited. I must "trouble you to remit me 2001. as I cannot in pru-dence undertake the continuance of this important " cause without the costs being secured to me your " faithful servant, DEDIMUS DUPLEX."

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ruin, Ruin!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh, here's a bit of a postscript—" A Mr. Tangent—"

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: MQuary.
sp.p: What's the matter? (reads)"A Mr. Tangent has been frequently inquiring after you."

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: How unlucky!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That you did not see him?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: y—ye—yes— sir—

sp.speaker: McQuery
sp.p: How lucky then! for I saw him just now.
Flulk. In this town? M'Query. Yes; I'll bring him here in a crack

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Hold! not for the world.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p:
Not for the world! what makes you tremble? Oh, ho! there's a bit of a secret, and I must be master of it (aside.) Come, an't I your friend?
Did not I come and offer my friendship and assistance, without even knowing you?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You did so.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And an't I still ready with my friendship and service?—and I will assist you.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Will you, will you, sir? Indeed I want it. Hear then my unhappy story; but swear by sacred honour.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: If you've a bit of a bible, I'll take my oath—honour's all moonshine!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: No, sir. Honour, is the conversation of society: without it, even our virtues wou'd be dangerous. It tempers courage, and vice it puts to shame; it irradiates truth, and mixes up opposing passions in the sweet compound of urbanity.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh, very true; (aside) I'll pop that into my next brief. Oh, it will make a flashy speech for one of our fine pathetic barristers. But now for the secret. Whatever you communicate shall be locked here, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
It was my fate to marry contrary to my father's will, and I was driven by misfortune to India; where, after a residence of eighteen years, the news reached me of my father's decease, and that at his death he had done me the justice he refused me living. I was about to return to England to take possession of my estates, when the service demanded my assistance to check the inroads of a powerful banditti that infested the frontier.—In a skirmish, Lieutenant Richmond, a brave
lad, fell by my side—he gave to my care one thousand pounds, as a bequest to his friend Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: So far, so well.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: On my return, sir, I found my wife dying. I am sorry to trouble you with hearing my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Don't mention it—'tis a pleasure—you found your wife dying.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And my patrimony, as you know, usurped by a distant and wealthy relation—I endeavoured to find Mr. Tangent—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh no!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Indeed I did, sir—distresses came upon me—arrears for my daughter's education—the expences of my wife's funeral.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Nobody wou'd grudge that, sure.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And the hopes of recovering my right by law, induced me, sir, to, to—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Make use of Mr. Tangent's money.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Y—yes—sir. I doubted not but I cou'd soon replace it. I had considerable prize-money due— aye, and somewhat hardly earn'd—but it is not paid. Involved with agents, proctors—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Aye, and sweet pretty picking it is.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Then, sir, I hoped soon to recover my estates. But the progress of the law, is, you know, so very slow—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: We don't—we don't hurry ourselves certainly.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now, sir, wou'd you advance the money to pay Mr.—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Why, you don't mean to pay it, do you?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Don't bother yourself about such a trifle— pay him! pugh! stuff! Between ourselves, I thought you had been dabbling in a little forgery.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Villain! (seizes him. M'Query smiles) Oh. I beg pardon—you are pleasant.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Yes, I am very pleasant; and I wish I cou'd return the compliment. (aside) What a tiger! However, I'm glad you have the cash, because—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Even now, I gave the last guinea I possess'd to my daughter.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That's unlucky! Because here's a little bit of a bill for labour, trouble, care and diligence, as we say.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: This, then, is your proffer'd assistance.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh, read it, read it. You'll find it right to an eightpence.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: "Attending you frequently to offer my advice and friendship without being able to meet you, two pounds two."

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That's right and proper, and 'tis all like it; but as you've no cash, you may as well sign a little bit of a bond and judgment: it will make the debt an even fifty.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Aye, any thing.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: 'Tis a pity you're so poor.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Hush! for heaven's sake—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I'm worth twenty thousand.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You're a lucky man, sir.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Here's a bond ready.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Within there! Bring pen and ink.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Ha, ha! You forget you have not a parcel of servants now. That's a good one, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ha, ha! I did so, sir.—Damnation! is life worth holding on these terms? We shall find them in the next room.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Now, sir, tho' you have put yourself in my power—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Hah! in your power—shallow fool! mark me. Dare but to hint at what I've told you, and by the honour I have lost, your life pays the forfeit—do you mark? In your power! Do you mark, I say?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: O yes! I was not in earnest. I was pleasant again. Oh, what a devil he is! 'tis hard to be so poor—I'm worth twenty thousand, every shilling.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: This way. Unfeeling man!

div3.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Clementina.
sp.p: How do I look, Fanny? Do you know, Fanny, my dead aunt was quite teizing—I declare and vow she once sent for me to see her die, and I found her dancing a Scotch reel at an assembly. How horrid provoking! Have you an idea, Fanny, how much one ought to cry for an aunt?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I dont really know, miss.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh Fanny, you lived with lady Eschallot when her husband died. Did she make it a point to take on?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: O yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Did it tell, Fanny?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Exceedingly, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I dare say it wou'd be stylish, 'tis so particular. Oh! I shall have oceans of lovers when I get this fortune. 'Tis so shocking to be constant, I vow— after you have cut your jokes and shown your tricks, it grows so insipid, and you do long for another lover
in such a style, you've no idea. Here comes pa—Do you know, Fanny, that pa's keeping a shop horrifies me to that degree—

sp.stage: Enter ALLSPICE, with his velvet cap and apron on.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Ah, Cleme—what! dizen'd out—expect to touch the mopusses, eh?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Indeed, pa, I'm reduc'd to despair to see you out of mourning.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: First let's see the will. Time enough to mourn when I find there's something to rejoice at. I wish Caustic would come—busy day, Cleme. As sheriff, I must usher the judges into the town—as tradesman, must attend my customers—so, what between the judges in the court, and the old women in the shop, I've my hands full.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, and Mr. M'Query, sir.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Ah, friend Caustic, glad to see you—servant, Mr. Attorney—come, bring chairs, read quick, —never mind stops—busy day.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Miss Clementina, how do you do? These are rather gay habiliments for mourning.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, no observations. As pa says, read.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: With all my heart—except the colour, gay as a bride.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Dont be impertinent, man.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And the head too—heigho! Well, here is the will, and thus I break the seal—now for it.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Ay, now for it.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I, Sarah Sapless, spinster, being of sound and disposing mind, do make this my last will and testament. Imprimis, I bequeath to my worthy brother-in-law, Toby Allspice.—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, she was an excellent old woman!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: "Toby Allspice, the sum of five pounds—"

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: "The sum of five pounds, to purchase a ring."

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: A ring.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Fiddlededee! Superannuated old fool.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Silence! And whereas my wayward fate has deprived me of the comforts of wedlock, and as I sincerely believe that nothing can tend more to the benefit of society, than promoting the happiness of faithful lovers—very extraordinary this!—I do hereby bequeath to Walter Caustic, esquire, all my estates, personal and real—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I bequeath to Walter Caustic, esquire, all my estates, personal and real,—in trust—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh, in trust!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I hate trusts.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Silence, sir. Go on.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: In trust, to settle and convey the same as a marriage portion upon any young woman he may think worthy, who may be about to become a bride, within the space of one month after my decease.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Ecod, its a queer one.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: "And whereas—"

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That's 'all that's material, except a bit of a codicil.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, is not my name in the will?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No, miss.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Pa!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Cleme!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Do you know, pa, that being disappointed of thirty thousand pounds, is extremely disagreeable?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Very, Cleme.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: All that's material? What's this, and this?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That, you know, is description and specification; and saying it over and over again, to make the thing look plump and decent.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Now for the codicil! I, the within named, Sarah Sapless, do make this codicil, which I do order and direct may be taken as part of my said will, and by which I do hereby bequeath to Phelim M'Query, my attorney, in lieu of his bill, one thousand pounds— Very moderate recompense!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Very moderate! But 'tis enough—Oh, 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
This, certainly is the most extraordinary;
Ha, ha, ha! To select me for the high priest of Hymen, to make me a wither'd Cupid, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: The cavalcade is ready to move, and only waits for your honour.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Then get my gown and wig; and my white wand. 'Tis very awful!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: You look alarm'd—I've seen you before a judge without being frighten'd.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Aye; but that was when I was a greater man than the judge, foreman of the jury—and then I'm not afraid of the devil.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: If you don't think my diffidence may increase yours, I'll attend.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Oh, no danger!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Well, now I commence the perfect gemman. Damn it, stand back, (to M'Query) I must go first. Dick, fill this box with backy—Roger, yoke the coach.

div3.stage: CAUST. is going, when CLEM, curtsies, and stops him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, you were polite enough to find fault with my dress—I'll alter my gown any way you please, sir.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: So, here's a change! (aside) By no means, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But you have discernment, sir.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I have a little, ma'am. (sarcastically) Good morning.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: When may we expect the honour of seeing you again, sir?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Tangent will be here. Miss Clementina, I intend to introduce to you my nephew, Mr. Tangent. Should he come before I return, I hope you'll welcome him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Dear sir! Oh! oh! Mr. Tangent and I, then, are to be the happy pair. (aside) Dear Mr. Caustic, I hope you have quite abandon'd your gout. I declare and vow, I was horrified at hearing you were ill.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, I expected death.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Do you know that's extremely disagreeable. I hope you will make it a point to keep well, Mr. Caustic. Pray take care of the steps—If you shou'd slip, I shou'd scream in such a style, you have no idea. I must attend you.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: You are too good. No.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I shall expire if I don't. Take care, dear Mr. Caustic.

div3.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p:
I'm afraid ma'am, you'll find the parcel rather
ther heavy—I'll send it home. There's your change, ma'am.
sp.stage: Enter TANGENT (sits down in a chair).

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Shopman, is Mr. Caustic here?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: He's gone, sir; but will return presently.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Very well—I'll wait for him.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: You'd better walk into the house, sir:—the shop—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I like the shop. Is your mistress, miss Clementina within, oh!

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I don't much relish this affair. However, it humours old Caustic so,—d'ye hear? tell her Mr. Tangent wishes to pay his respects—What are you about?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Oh. I dare not go before miss with my apron on—she says its vulgar.
sp.stage: Exit. (after having put his apron on the chair)

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ignorant prejudice! (putting the apron round him) By heavens, 'tis as honest an appendage, aye, and of as much benefit to society too, as many long robes I've seen. (sets) Tired to death of the courts—either as dull as a country church, or as vulgar as Billingsgate.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I presume, sir, you belong here.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
I, ma'am! heavens, what an angel! Ma'am—No— (looking at himself) Oh yes—
yes, ma'am—I belong to the shop. (throwing away his hat) What a lovely creature!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is Mr. Richard at home?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, ma'am, Dicky has just stept out, ma'am—Interesting beyond description!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Then I must trouble you for these articles.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Proud to serve you, ma'am—just take down the day-book—now I shall know my angel's name and abode. To be sent, ma'am, to—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: There's something very extraordinary in this young man—Sir, I'll send for them—Good morning.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: S'death! I shall lose her—Stop, ma'am, I beg pardon—but here are exactly the articles you want, ready packed, and I shall be happy in attending you home with them, ma'am—exceedingly happy.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: His deportment and dress seem much above his situation—Sir I can't think of troubling you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Trouble, ma'am! Never above my business. I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But there is none to attend the—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, ma'am, Dicky is only in the house. What shall I do for a hat? (Sees a small one hanging up, puts it on) Ma'am, I'll follow you—Dicky, mind the shop, Dicky—Oh, an angel! What the devil have I got here? 'tis infernally heavy. I'll follow you, ma'am—Dicky, take care of the shop.

div3.stage: Enter CLEM. (with her eyes fix'd on the ground) and SHOPMAN.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent, your most obedient—I declare and vow— (Looks up, then at the shopman) Where's Mr. Tangent, fellow?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: I left him here, ma'am, with my apron.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Then he's gone.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Ecod, and so is my apron.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Now, whether this is shocking vulgar, or extremely stylish, I've not the minutest atom of an idea. I dare say 'tis genteel.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Not to take my apron.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh, I'm sure 'tis fine breeding; for there's a certain brutality in high life that's enchanting. (huzza without) What horrid yell is that?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: 'Tis my master, the sheriff, miss, come from the show, huzza!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Silence, brute!

div3.stage: Enter ALLSPICE (with sheriff's gown and wig, wiping his face).

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Thank God 'tis over! I'd rather throw a hundred sugar loaves into a cart, than go thro' it again. Well, Cleme, how goes on the shop?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You know, pa, I hate the shop.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p:
Oh fie, Cleme! don't let me hear you say that again. You dog, is that the way to tie up a parcel? (to shopman, and gives a box on the ear) Confound
these trappings! Get me my apron, Cleme, will you?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I declare and vow, pa, your vulgarity horrifies me. Suppose you were to go to court with an address, and be knighted, wou'd not your manners—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Me knighted! Fiddlestick's end. When such chaps as I go to get dubb'd, if, instead of a sword, his majesty wou'd but order one of his beef-eaters, to lay a stick across our shoulders, it wou'd be a hundred percent the better.

div3.stage: Enter sheriff's servant, drest in the absurdity of lace, large hat, &c.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Maister!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. sheriff, Brute!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You see I bes dizen'd out in new livery, he, he!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Take off your hat, savage.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I canna, miss—Man has stuckn'on so fast, he winna came off—he, he!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Geoffry, 'tis hard to tell whether you or I look most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ecod, maister, I think you have it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Who's at the door?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Wauns I forgot. It be maister Dashall fra Lunnun.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, my friend, Dashall—show him in. But let me get off these trappings—The Londoner will smoke me.
Ah, Dashall! Glad to see you. Ecod, you look comical tho'. Why, Dick, either your head or mine must be devilishly out of fashion—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Why, friend Toby, yours is more on the grand pas to be sure. But very little head, you see, serves people of fashion. So—there's the thirty thousand pounder, I suppose. I say, Toby, who is that elegant creature?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: 'Tis my daughter. Don't you remember Cleme!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: You're an angel!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Go, Cleme, and look after the people—To day, I give grand—ga ga—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Gala, pa! I've told you the name twenty times—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Confound it! Gala then.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Sir, your most devoted.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I adore you.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh, sir!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To distraction, damme.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I vow you confuse me in such a style.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, I see that account's settled— (looking after her) and now for the father. Oh, how does it tell?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: What, that's the knowing, is it?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To be sure. But, Toby, how did you come on at the courts?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, capitally. I made a speech

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A speech?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes, I did. Sam Smuggle you must know was found guilty of taking a false oath at the Custom House; so the judge order'd me to put Sam in the pillory. "An please you, my lord judge," says I, "I'd rather not." "Why so, Mr. sheriff?" Because, my lord, says I, "Sam Smuggle, no more than a "month ago, paid me 37l. 18s. 11d. as per ledger, and I make it a rule never to disoblige a customer"—Then they a laughed—So you see I came off pretty well.

sp.speaker: Desh.
sp.p: Capitally. But an't you tired of this sneaking retailing

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, yes, sometimes of a Saturday—Market day.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: 'Tis a vile paltry bore. What do you make by this raffish shop of yours?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, a great deal. Last year 1745l. odd money.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Contemptible! my clerk wou'd despise it. Why, in a single monopoly I've touch'd ten times the sum.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Monopoly?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To be sure—the way we knowing ones thrive. You remember that on sugar—a first rate thing, was it not?—distressed the whole town—made them take the worst commodity at the best price: netted fifteen thousand pounds by that.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Why, I turned the penny by that myself.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p:
Turned the penny! be advised by me, and
you shall turn thousands,—ay, and overturn thousands.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Shall I tho'? but did you sell all that sugar yourself?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I fell! never saw a loaf. No, my way is this—I generally take my first clerk a hunting with me; and when the hounds are at fault, we arrange these little matters.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: How free and easy! oh, you must be gloriously rich.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I won't tell you my circumstances just now.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh you're sly—you've your reasons.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I have. I'm very expensive in my women tho'.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Ah! mothers and sisters extravagant?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Mothers and s;isters! no, no.—Curse me if I know how they carry on the war. Take in the flats at faro I suppose. No, I mean, the girls.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: What! not concubines, do you?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To be sure. But perhaps you don't like the girls, eh?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh but I do tho'—I'll tell you a melancholy secret. Do you know that people in the country are so precise, and talk so about character, that, my dear friend, in the particular you mentioned, I am a very unhappy man.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, is it there I have you? then come to town, my gay fellow, enjoy affluence and pleasure, and make a splash.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p:
Ecod, I shou'd like it. Even talking about
it, gives me a kind of swaggering, agreeable feel: and then the girls—the pretty profligates!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, you shall have my Harriet.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Shall I? I'll do all I can to make her happy, yes, I will: and if she likes almonds and raisins, she shall have—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Almonds and raisins! pearls and diamonds!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes; but how am I to get them?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: You've heard of the Alley?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes; but I don't understand it. Bulls and bears—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I'll make you up to all—Cons—Rescounters, short stuff, bonus, backwardation, omnium gatherum—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Aye; and what's being a lame duck?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I'll shew you the way to be that too. I'll teach you the true waddle—let you into twenty good things besides. We knowing ones have form'd a most capital plan for starving the nation.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Aye, but you forget that other knowing ones have formed a capital plan for preventing the starving of the nation.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Still I've a resource.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Have you? egad, you're a clever fellow.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Come here.—If corn market don't answer, ship it coastwise—insure it—vessel leaky—stress of weather—come to an anchor—cut out by an enemy's privateer—all settled before-hand—receive value of cargo there—touch insurance at home—do them both ways—knowing scheme.—The inventors will be immortal.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: And if I had my will, they should be immortal in a week. Supply an enemy! dam'me if I do that.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, ho! bad voyage this, I must about ship.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: I love money dearly and I love the pretty girls, but—

sp.speaker: Dash,
sp.p: And Harriet will adore you.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, do you say so? I tell you what I'll do—I'll start gallant to day—I'll make a splash among the ladies at my—what's the name on't?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Gala. But you must get rid of that porcupine frizzle. You must be cropt in this way.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Bless you, I've plenty of hair under my wig.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: That's lucky (aside)—So—I've got him pretty tight in hand.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: You'll see how I'll ogle and swagger. Come along. Oh, Toby's the boy to tickle them.

div3.head: SCENE II.A Room in FAULKNER'S House,

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Does my attorney in town refuse to proceed?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Without cash he does.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: He knows the law is with me to a certainty.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Law and certainty! you really forget what you are talking about.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Most likely: far I am mad.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I'm sorry for you, Captain, indeed I am; tho' I'm only an attorney, I'm sorry.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Oh, sir, don't outrage your tender nature.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, your most obedient—I call'd, sir, respecting—but you're engaged.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Pray, sir, be seated.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: My business, sir, is of so little importance either to you or myself, that—he seems agitated—I'll take another opportunity—good morning—I'll just take a peep into the courts, and see how Tangent comes on in the law—oh, he'll be chancellor.

div3.stage: Enter JULIA, followed by TANGENT, carrying the Parcel—JULIA bows to CAUSTIC, in passing.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Zounds! my uncle!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Eh! what!—yes—no—it can't be!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Well, my dear, have you made your purchases?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Yes, sir; the real black hyson—sweet, pretty article—defies the trade to sell more cheaperer than us do—ma'am (bowing to Julia, and peeping at Caustic) oh—he knows me.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: 'Tis he, by all that's furious.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Not quite so familiar, if you please, sir. Well recollected—I want—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And I want—patience.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: We don't sell it, sir.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Oh, you incorrigible—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, is it you? how do you do, uncle?—must brazen it out.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, sir, what's that? (pointing to the apron) and what the devil are you at now?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Trade—commerce, uncle—soul of sir Thomas Gresham—thou, who in the compting-house of the gods, sittest—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Stop, stop, I say—have you forgot the woolsack?—think of the woolsack!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I do—wool is a staple commodity. Commerce, I say—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I say, law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The theory of commerce is abstruse, and very little understood.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Why, so is law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Commerce shews you what money will do.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: So does law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Commerce enriches the country.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: So does—no, no!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Sir, as father to this lady, I must demand an explanation of such extraordinary conduct.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: With all my heart. Sir, your lovely daughter came to Allspice's shop, when—I don't recollect how—but somehow or other, I had got this apron round me—she took me for the shopman; and for the pleasure of beholding her, I became a porter, and to continue that happiness, wou'd become (seeing M' Query)—an attorney. This is the fact: I can't tell a lie for the soul of me.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Can't you? then I wou'd recommend you not to become an attorney.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
Trade's the thing, uncle—understand it all—
I'll ship off a yard of ribbon with e'er a six-foot haberdasher in town, return the drawer to it's place with a smack—roll up change in a bit of paper—smirk—present it with the counter-bow—an't I perfect, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Tangent! damnation!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I cast you off, sir, for ever! 'sdeath! were you my own child, your undutiful conduct wou'd be natural and excusable. But you've no right to make me miserable—I'm not your father, and I insist—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And I insist that my house may not be made the scene of your buffoonery.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Upon my soul, sir, I—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And that you take leave of it, and that lady for ever.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh sir, surely—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Girl!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: There—I'm glad on't. And now, sir, you may think of the woolsack, sir, or you may snip ribbons, sir—or wrap up halfpence in whiteybrown paper sir—I have' done with you, sir—and there's the counter-bow for you, sir. Captain Faulkner, good morning.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
Captain Faulkner! then I may hear of my friend. Sir, tho' your conduct to me has been harsh, I flatter myself, unmeritedly so, yet my anxiety to hear
of a lost friend induces me to solicit what I shou'd otherwis;e despise.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Be brief, sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Charles Richmond—Charles Richmond, sir —is he no more?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: He fell by my side.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Poor Charles! I remember, when we were at college, we agreed, that whoever died batchelor, shou'd make the survivor his heir; but he was too generous to be rich. Did he, sir, leave any money?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Not—not—that I—know of—agony!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No, not that he knows of. I'll bring you off.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Be dumb!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, he must have died poor; for villany itself could not wrong so noble a fellow.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Fiends! tortures!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Died poor, certainly. Do you suppose now, that if he had given any money to Mr. —

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Silence, dog!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Every dog has his day!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: With Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I'll not trust you. Dare not for your life speak to him.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I suppose I may go home.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: This way then. Remember, I am no trifler. This way I say.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Madam, am I to conclude so trivial a levity could occasion Captain Faulkner's behaviour, or—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, I am wholly ignorant (sighs.). I never saw my father so before.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And may I hope, loveliest of women, that the sentiments of that tender bosom—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, the sentiment that governs here, is implicit obèdience to a father's will. He is returning. Pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: May I not hope, miss Faulkner, that—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I beg, sir—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Only—farewell!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: How eccentric, yet how interesting! what can my father mean?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Is he gone? thank heaven!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Pray, sir, has Mr. Tangent—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Do you combine to torture?—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, my father, kill me, but do not frown on me.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Kill thee, Julia.—Oh, I'm to blame.—But my mind is in agony.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: May I not share it? may I not alleviate it?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: No, no.—We must leave this town to-day.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Thy father, Julia, is a beggar.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Worse—He has contracted debts he cannot discharge, and must, like a rascal, fly.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Bear up, my heart!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, worse — Thy father is — But why should I agonize her more?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, don't despair.—We shall do very well. I can work, indeed I can—I am a strong girl—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Revive, my child!—I shelter'd thee from misery while it was possible.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is what your ancestors left you, lost, all lost?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Yes, Julia, all— (aside) for they left me honour.—But we must fly.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Whither, my father?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Any where, to avoid—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I charge thee, name him not.—Go in.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, my father, do not leave me—I, dread being alone.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I will but ruminate awhile, then come to thee.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But, presently?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But, very soon?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Yes, my child:—go in.

Well, I lied it stoutly—the veriest rascal, that eats the bread of perjury, could not have lied it with more unblushing boldness. Where shall, I fly? the poor honest man, e'en in this knavish world, has some few friends, the rich villain more; but the poor rascal— Ha! first a thief, and then a liar—what follows? some devil whispers, a self-murderer. But oh! can I leave my girl to poverty, to scorn, to dishonour?—No, no!
we part not. What remains?—To go to Tangent—crawl in the dust, and be spurn'd by him!—rot and damn first!—despair then is only left: for the world's palliations, as degrees of guilt—the law of necessity will not give comfort here. No, to the truly proud, the first step from honour is perdition.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father! you said you'd come to me— don't be angry. Oh, do you smile on me? then Julia cannot be unhappy (embraces Faulkner). You frown'd just now—'twas the first time: indeed it cut my heart. Come, sir, be chearful; for poverty cannot chill the conscious glow of virtue, nor dim the celestial radiance of honour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Lady Sorrel to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Desire lady Sorrel to walk in. Exit servant, and re-enter with lady Sorrel. Your most obsequious, my lady. How am I to have the honour of serving you? Is it your will I'm to make?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: My will, sir!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh what a blunder! Because ladies often make their wills, when they shou'd be making their marriage articles.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: You gentlemen of the long robe flatter.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You flatter, my lady! I of the long robe! No, I'm only, as I may say, a mere spencer of the law—Oh, how I love female clients! They are so easily pleas'd— (aside) and so easily imposed on.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p:
You are too polite. But that is the characteristic of Ireland—I've been there: and had I
remained, it is a country I shou'd have been transported with.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And had I remained there, it is a country I shou'd have been transported from.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent, who possesses many amiable qualities—in my approbation of men, sir, I always use discernment.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh you do— (aside) For you always approve of young ones.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: He has fallen in love with a miss Faulkner, whose father is, I hear, poor and proud. Pray, sir, do you know any thing about him?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: A little: and one thing I know, is, that he owes me fifty pounds, and has not a shilling to pay me.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Indeed! If any thing cou'd prevent Tangent's attachment to the lady (a little witch) it wou'd certainly be for their good.—Does it strike you how you cou'd be of service to this captain and his fair daughter?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: What do you think of sending them to —to—jail?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Jail! (aside) Faith, that's one way of being of service. Why, it's a good place for them to recollect themselves in.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: And would prevent Tangent's seeing her.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And, bring down the pride of the father.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: And, as they are poor, wou'd contract their expenses.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Apartment found them for nothing there, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Well, then, as captain Faulker owes you money, suppose you were to arrest—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh I can't—I can't in honour, because (aside) I shou'd get nothing by it. Here is his bond. Now, many people take fancies to bonds—for my part, I'd just as soon have ready money—It's a mighty pretty bond; and if you purchase it, I'll send him to jail with all the pleasure in life; for then, you know, I'm only an attorney in the business; and 'tis no matter what I do.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: How fortunate! Now I shall be revenged. Very well. Assign it to me; and, as we agree it will be for their good, you may as well arrest—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Yes; I'll give the captain a wholesome tap on the shoulder. In the next room is parchment, pen, and ink.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I am going to Allspice's gala. I suppose you will be there to pay your court to the barristers?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No; I go there to have the barristers pay court to me. You'll see the young ones crowd about me, like a plate full of potatoes round a butterboat, and try to wheedle me out of a light half guinea. Oh, miss Faulkner is no more to be compared to you, madam, than a little twinkling star is to the full moon.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Ah, sir, flattery's another characteristic of your country.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p:
My words exactly express my meaning,
my lady; and that's another characteristic of my country.

div3.head: SCENE II.
div3.stage: A spacious suite of Rooms, brilliantly illiuminated,—music playing—card tables, &c.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What a horrid, capricious, old wretch that Mr. Caustic is! Just now, when, to humour him, I praised his nephew, he insisted I should not name him. Well, I vow I'm glad of that; for Mr. Dashall is far more tonish. I observed him to-day, with his hands in his pockets, elbowing every body, treading on the ladies' toes, and without any apology, tearing their dresses in such a style—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A gay thing, ma'am, faith—all elegance—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Except pa. Oh, sir, did you hear him at dinner? He rose up— (all the company were silent, expecting a complimentary address) and roars out, "Ladies and gentlemen, pray don't spare the pickles, for there are plenty in the shop." Oh, I blushed in such a style.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ha, ha! Upon my soul—and all that— you're a fine creature! and interest my feelings more than any event, since Waxy, the race-horse, won the Derby.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How flattering! How elegant! will you love me, sir?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: May virtue seize me, if, when we're married, I don't adore you!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Adore me!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes; that is, fashionably.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: You would not have us found together debtor and creditor, in your father's ledger, or stuck together like his figs.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh! shocking!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No; ours shall be a stylish adoration—separate beds—you making a dash with your friend in one curricle; I making a splash with mine in another. You at Bath—I at Newmarket—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh charming! Hail, connubial love! Oh, here comes Mr. Caustic.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Then you shall see me hoax him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh no. It is he that has the disposal of my aunt's fortune.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, that's the reason that all the women were paying court to him. I swear, he look'd like the grand signior with a seraglio at his heels.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But it all won't do. I am the favour'd sultana.

div3.stage: At the top of the stage, enter CAUSTIC bowing to a number of ladies about him, who pass off.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
Ma'am, your most obedient—miss, your devoted. Good-day, madam—oh, miss, happy to see you. (coming forward) Oh my back! my back! I must go home, ha, ha! But I can't help laughing at
the absurd adulation paid me. I who was yesterday a sour curmudgeon, am to-day the monopolizer of all human excellence. Oh my poor back! Oh world! world!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How do you do, sir?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Your most obedient.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I hope, sir, you approve of our music and gala.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: To say the truth, madam, I preferr'd my own.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Your own, I vow! Pray, when did you give a gala, Mr. Caustic?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: In the last frost, madam, to two hundred paupers and their helpless families—and we had our dancing too, ma'am: for the little chubby brats in merry anticks gambol'd round my knees: and we had music too, madam; for the widows sung for joy.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh charming!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Damn'd fine indeed! I think with you certainly, sir, that—what the devil is the word? Benevolence, is it not?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes, there is such a word—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye—benevolence, virtue, and all that, are at times extremely amusing.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Amusing! sir, virtue is the business of our lives; all else is its idleness.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I vow, sir, I was shocked to see you so teized by the fulsome attentions of the women. Flattery is not way to secure the approbation of a man—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Of your fine feelings and understanding.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: It is not indeed! (aside) Madam, Mr. Allspice wants you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Favour me with your hand.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Sir, your devoted. Ah, what worlds of feeling!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What oceans of sense! (apart) I fancy we've tickled him in a capital style.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Very neatly, too! ha, ha!
sp.stage: Exeunt smiling and nodding approbation to each other.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: These excite but laughter and contempt; but my vexatious nephew's tormenting.—But this I'm resolved on,—if ever again he dare to—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Julia Faulkner! Julia Faulkner! By heaven, her beauty might set the world at war, and make another siege of Troy: and oh! were I general at that siege, I'd build castles—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Aye, that you wou'd!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! What shou'd'oppose me? Sword in hand I'd storm the breach— (pushing between two chairs) I'd fire the palace, pull down the gates— (snatches up a chair) and rush into her arms, (is near embracing Caustic)—ah, uncle, is it you?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Keep off! How dare you approach me, you—are you not a pretty fellow?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: So the ladies say, sir.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And a fool?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: So I say, sir.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And a libertine?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: So you say, sir.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And what do you say for yourself?—A profess'd libertine?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I say that I practise what I profess; which is more than you moralists can say.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Psha! and the world says you're a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Damn the world then for making me one. How the devil can I help being a coxcomb, when I see a flattering fool like myself idolized, and modest worth despised? Uncle, the temple of Folly wou'd soon be without votaries, had it not the world for its worshippers.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: But zounds! did the world clap you on the woolsack? did the world put you on an apron, or desire you to make another siege of Troy?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Upon my soul, I'm asham'd of myself; but by future perseverance and diligence, I'll atone for my follies. Come, uncle, forgive the past—shake hands.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: No—well—there—aye, Frank, persevere, and you may soon convert your air-built castle into a solid one of brick and mortar.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: True; then every one will say, his character does not rest on the flimsy basis of hereditary worth, but on the noble exertion of talent.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: That's well said.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Then I with conscious dignity will walk thro' my hall—my servants ranged on each side—I bend to them with ease, call my agent, and say to him, distribute an hundred pounds to—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Death and fury, you're at it again!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, no—that was only—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: What will drive me mad. 'Sdeath! what is talent without the will and means to exert it? 'Tis Newton without his telescope, or Handel without his organ.—Remember, this is your last, last warning!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: He's certainly right. That Handel was a great man; and tho' bereft of one sense, how amply was another gratified! For what can strike more gratefully on the heart, than hearing the honourable applause of an impartial public?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I'll just take a peep, and see the effect my lecture has had.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tho' Handel was blind, how I envy him his sensations, when, seated before an enraptured audience, he thus began, and charmed all hearts— (shuts his eyes and plays on the table) Oh, charming! bravo!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: You villain! if ever I speak to you again, may I—I discard you for ever—for ever—and for ever!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, confound this crack'd head! What a scrape have I got into.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
So, here's the wife he intends for me. Marry
her, and doat on Julia. Sweet situation mine wou'd be! I can very well fancy myself—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Brute! sir, my pa wishes to speak—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll come to your pa. (ruminating, and not looking at her) No, Julia, I'll be only thine—I'll come to your pa.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: This way, sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll come to your pa—I'll be only thine, my Julia—I'll come to your pa—
sp.stage: (follows Clementina to one side of the stage, and walks cut absorb'd in thought at the opposite side

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Gone! Well, this is certainly beyond all the fine breeding I ever saw—Miss Faulkner?

div3.stage: Enter JULIA, in great agitation, her hair disorder'd.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, madam, forgive this intrusion—you told me you had a friendship for me. Oh, show it now! my father is arrested—in a dreadful situation.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: So are you, my dear, in a dreadful situation. Never kneel in a public room.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Madam, I said my dear father,—the beloved author of my being, is in a prison.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Well! we're ruined, madam.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: That's certainly extremely disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Oh, my dear, don't mind It—arrested! Nothing can be more fashionable. I dare say all will be well. Good bye! I'm sorry I can't assist you but the
guinea loo-table waits for me. Pray come and see me when your affairs are settled. Good bye, my dear! Good bye! Good bye!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: This, in prosperity, was my warmest friend. Alas! such friends are as the leaves that clothe the tree in the genial summer, but leave it naked to the winter's blast. Whither shall I go? Heavens! Mr. Tangent!
Sir—hold! did not my father forbid my speaking to him? But is not that father in want?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Married to a woman I dislike.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Married! Oh, my heart! Julia, this is no time for thy sorrows.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! if I'm miserable, what signifies my having thousands in my pocket's?—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: How fortunate!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Marry for thirty thousand! Psha! (takes box) With decent luck I'd win it in ten minutes.—Did you say, sir, you'd set me 500l.—done! Seven's the main, and six I have—off in two throws a thousand—done—six it is! Bravo! Come, gentlemen, a thousand each if you please.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent, I want—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Double or quit? you shall have it (turning round.)—Heavens! miss Faulkner! damn this head of mine—it's in such a whirl.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, sir, pity and relieve!

div3.stage: Enter DASHALL at the back Scene.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What's here? fine girl, faith!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I know my behaviour is wild, is imprudent, but my excuse is, a father in prison and broken hearted—save but him.—For myself I care not.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: By heaven she puts herself in my power, and what an exquisite temptation! here's an opportunity to establish my character as a man of gallantry! hold! here's an opportunity to establish my reputation as a man of honour. The father of my love in prison, and I without change for sixpence—I'll go this instant and borrow money at 500 percent.—I'll—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I'm sure you'll relieve me—I'm sure you have a generous heart. The debt is but fifty pounds. I heard you say had thousands in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ma'am, I said—that—I—that is I—Oh! curse this crack'd head! but I'll get the money instanly. Miss Faulkner, it is with shame and confusion I declare, that at this moment it is not in my power to be of the least assistance.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is it possible? is this the man to whom I've given my heart?—'tis too much (is near fainting, when Dashall runs to her assistance) ah! a stranger!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p:
Don't be alarmed, young lady— (aside) I see I must give her a touch of the sober citizen. Madam, I heard your distress; I am inquisitive after sorrow— I possess a large fortune, 'tis true; but only in trust for the worthy who want it. A sober, plodding citizen,
as you see, plain in my manners, plainer in my dress—despise powder and embroidery—a mere London merchant!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: The world knows their benevolence.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pretty well. But you must not suppose all London merchants like me.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Will you, sir—will you, then, save my father? I can't expresss what I feel.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: That's very odd! when I can so well express what I do not feel. Madam, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Then, sir, I'll expect you at the prison where my father is.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, no!—I can't tell you why; but I have a strange antipathy to prisons. But in two hours time at the gate of it, if you please.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, I'll bless you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Upon my foul I mean it. Now I suppose I shou'd say gallant things, but I cannot. Suffice it, I will be there.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Farewell!—happy, happy Julia!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I will be there ready— Exit Julia. with a post-chaise and four to carry you off, my nice one—then chevy, away for the next town—confine her—swear she's a runaway wife—return—marry miss Allspice—do old Toby out of the ready. Ha, ha! here he comes—what a gig it is!

sp.stage: Enter ALLSPICE, his hair cropt, a full-dress coat on, singing—
sp.p: "Lovely Nymph, assuage my anguish."

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Well, here I am—as gay a dasher as the best of you—snug about the head, eh?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But what a quiz of a coat you've on!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Don't you like it? it was my grandfather's.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Your dinner was stylish, faith.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Very; but it had one little fault. There was nothing to eat—grottoes, trees, fountains, sweetmeat shepherdesses, and buttered Cupids in plenty,—nothing else. I shou'd have been half starved, had I not luckily looked over my shoulder, and there beheld my old friend, the honoured sirloin, on the sideboard—I could have cried to see him so disgraced; but I order'd him to be conducted to the top of the table, and the music to strike up "Oh the Roast Beef of Old England!" and, then, how I ogled the girls, and how they titter'd at me! women give a man's ideas so elegant a turn. I'm as much above what I was, as a hogshead is to a butter firkin.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Butter firkin! curse it, and sink it, Toby, talk like a gentleman. But, I say, you seem a little damaged.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes; funny, an't I? I got hold of a little bottle, such as they put ketchup in—by the bye I can sell you some very fine ketchup, if you want any—It was devilish good, yoyeo they call it.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yoyeo! psha! noyau.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Well, well, noyau. Egad, when I found it cost a guinea, and that I was to pay for it—I drank it all every drop.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A guinea! bagatelle! I'll put you in a way to drink it every day.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: How, my dear friend:?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I've had a letter from my clerk.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Your hunting clerk?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes; he has a scheme of buying up furs, by which 100 per cent. must be made in a month.—A trifle—five thousand—will do; but at present my cash is here and there. Indeed at this moment I can't exactly tell you where it is, But if you should like it—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: You would not have me lay out five thousand pounds in muffs and tippets, wou'd you?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Five thousand! I've speculated deeper in darning needles.—But you have not the cash?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes but I have tho'—that sum in the house. too—I intended to buy with it half an estate valued at ten thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Then defer the purchase one month, and I'll engage you shall buy the whole.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh charming! ah, but should it fail—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But it can't fail—if it do, then blame me.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: That's enough.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: All you will have to do, will be to come to town in a month, and hug your ten thousand pounds, as sure as the sweet Harriet will hug you.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p:
Oh the pretty one! That has fixed me. When the company is gone, I'll give you bank notes to the amount:—and tell your hunting clerk, if he'll make the five thousand ten, I'll give him a guinea. Oh, what a rich, jolly dog I shall be! let's go and have another touch at the little bottle,—another guinea's worth—damn the expence! and drink confusion to
retailing, and Harriet's health in a bumper! "Lovely Nymph," &c.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: If this is'nt doing it, the devil's in it, ha, ha! I've bother'd the daughter, and tickled old Caustic in a capital style,—that's a dead thirty thousand.—Humbugged the old one here out of five, and shall carry off the nice girl to a certainty. What a splash I shall make along Cheapside! what a swagger I shall cut at Lloyd's! how the city bucks will stare, and, may be, dress at me. And then we shall have Birmingham Dashalls as well as Birmingham Dukes. Oh, I'm a neat article!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Come, come, the money—quick!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You'll pay devilish dear for it.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! that's my affair.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You must give your bond for five hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: What cash am I to touch?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Two. I can't afford more on my honour.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: My honour? yes, honour is the conservation of society—(Oh, I'wish I cou'd recollect Captain Faulkner's flashy speech)—Honour! is—upon my soul I can't tell what honour is.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I believe you. But you mention'd Captain Faulkner's name.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Yes. Oh, I could sell you a nice secret about him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tell me a secret, did you say.?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No—I said, sell you a secret.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Well, I am a buyer—any thing respecting him is interesting.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And you may get a thousand pounds by it.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Make your own terms.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Faulkner has humm'd you out of that sum.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Your friend, Charles Richmond, left it to you, and the old sly thief smushed it. He told a palavering story about distresses, and his dear daughter, and his wife's funeral, and a parcel of balderdash.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Poor Faulkner! my heart bleeds for him. This explains his behaviour.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
