sp.p: Then he has had a law-suit; but he's non-suited, as this letter will shew you

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Come, sir, draw the bond, (looks at the letter)—What's this? (reads) I remit you your share of the bribe for the error in Faulkner's declaration;—have also received, under his power of attorney, two thousand pounds prize-money. Scoundrels! Which is much better in our hands than his.—The more we distress him, the less danger there is of detection.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You see by that letter how things are, and what care I've taken of the Captain's property.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll put this in my pocket, and read it at leisure.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No, no—I'm always for vouchers—that letter shou'd not be lost.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: There I agree with you. Eh, I have it— (Tears off the half sheet with the contents of the letter, from the half sheet that, contains the address, wraps that up, and gives it to M'Query.) So—there's the letter.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Let me see (looking at it)—Now—that's as it should be

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Exactly—Is the bond ready?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Aye, sign away.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: But we have no witness.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh! I've a clerk will set his hand to it at any time—That Faulkner's a pretty fellow, is'nt he? To be sure, the coolness with which some people take others' property is amazing (taking up the bond)—In two hours' time you shall have the two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Very well; I must go, and tickle my old uncle, and then away to relieve poor Faulkner.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You've got the money very dear.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis false. The sensation I feel at this moment is cheap at ten times the sum.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Rather a neat morning's work.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Tangent?

sp.speaker: M'query
sp.p: This moment gone.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I hear the fool's in love with a miss Faulkner,—a female fortune-hunter, I suppose. Aye, like her fex—sharp as a razor.—You've found them so, I dare say.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh yes; and, like a razor, I've found strapping a mighty good thing for them.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And does he think I'll forgive this?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: He does. He says he'll tickle you.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Tickle me, will he'? we'll see that. Except in the article of money; there, indeed, he has reformed. Thank heaven, he don't borrow thousand of you now.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No—he only borrows five hundreds.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Eh! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: There's his bond, you see.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I'm petrified!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I'll sell it you.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Sell it me! he owes me thousands—a profligate! I shall be ruined—a beggar! but I'll humble him. He knows the way to tickle me, you know—now we'll see—arrest him—I'll shew him I can tickle him—I order you, sir, to arrest him.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: With all my heart and foul.—You will make the affidavit, and I will touch him up with a bit of a capias.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Aye, a capias. I'll humble him.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Then follow that up widi a fi—fa.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Aye, a fi—fa.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: If that won't do, tip him a ca—fa.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Aye, tip him a ca—fa. He can tickle me, can he? a profligate! come along!

div3.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: The chaise is ready, your honour.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Capital horses, eh?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Like myself—blood every inch.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Snug, you dog.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Oh, as sharp as my spurs.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: How surprised the girl will be, ha, ha! curse me if I can help laughing to think how she'll cry, ha, ha!
Bailiffs, by all that's—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ah, master Dashall, how are you?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: How do you do, Ned? how do you do?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You need not be afraid.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Afraid! no to be sure, I know that.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: We don't want you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Eh, don't you tho'?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Honour!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, honour

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Honour among thieves.

sp.speaker: Dash
sp.p: By the Lord you frighten'd me.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: We are not bailiffs now—we're in the mad line.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Mad line!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: We belong to Dr. Coercion, and are come after a patient that has escaped—a mad lawyer.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Mad lawyer! I always thought it was the client who was out of his senses. Well, good bye, Ned. 'Sdeath! here comes Tangent, perhaps to relieve Faulkner: and then I lose the girl—Eh, it would be knowing, he, he! here goes! so, Ned, you're come here after a mad lawyer.—Do you know his person?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I do, intimately; and, by heaven, here he comes! that's he—don't he look as if he was mad?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Oh, a clear case—now, this is so kind of you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: You'll take care of the poor fellow—ecod, Ned, you frighten'd me. Be sure now you take care of the poor devil, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Tom, mind your hits.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now to poor Faulkner's prison, and restore happiness to my Julia!—Julia! if I don't watch this addle-head of mine, I shall certainly go mad. There's something sublime in madness! rolling eye—dungeons—straw—chains—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Come, come, that will do—a pretty dsnce you've led us.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Who are you, and what do you want with me?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Tom, have you a strait waistcoat in your pocket?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Strait waistcoat! what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Take you back to the mad doctor's.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Be quiet, you scoundrels!

div3.stage: Enter SERVANT to CAUSTIC, and BAILIFFS.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: That's he you are to arrest. Touch him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, here's Caustic's servant. Come here, sir—am I mad, sir?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mad, sir? no, sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tell these rascals who I am.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Oh, this is Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Aye, Frank Tangent's my name, is not it?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: That it is.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You're an honest fellow!

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Then you shall go with an honest fellow—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: A writ! oh! the devil! worse and worse! at whose suit?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic's.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Pretty way I'm in! arrested at this moment! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Pay a visit to my lock-up-house.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I can't—'pon my honour I'm engaged—eh, I believe I'd better be mad (to Caustic's servant) ah! kneel down before your father and mother.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
I'm your father and mother. I'm father and
mother of all the judges—vanity's father and mother of all the counsellors—the devil's father and mother of all the bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He's mad.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Fudge! that's not madness.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I am mad, you scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I say he is mad.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: I say he an't mad

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll be off—ha! I spy a brother.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Mad or not, we must not lose him: so, come along.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Aye, aye; we must have him.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: By this time he's safe. I think I've given him a tickler, (noise) What! he resists, does he? (Reenter a servant) Well, sir, have they got him?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, sir: but he fought them nobly; then I came up.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And secured the rascal?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, your honour: I don't know how it was; but seeing three upon him, ecod, I coudn't help, somehow, fighting on his side; so I knock'd one down, and he killed another.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: What do you say? killed a man!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There he lies, bleeding like a pig.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Has my poor Frank been so rash? I hope he escaped.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No; they got hold of him.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I'm a miserable man—This is all my fault.
Is the man dead? oh, my poor boy!

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: No, your honour; the cowardly chap swooned at the sight of his blood.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Then the rascal has not killed him, eh?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: A guinea and a plaister will set all right.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Will it? he kill a man! what an old fool I was! hold, I have it. Let the man be conveyed to my house—give out his life's in danger. I'll have him taken up for a murderer: I'll lay him with the dust. Away with him to prison—I'll be so revenged! and, d'ye hear: put irons on him; (going) but don't starve him—give him bread and water, (going) and, d'ye hear, give him straw—give him plenty of straw.

div3.head: SCENE II.
div3.stage: FAULKNER discovered, JULIA leaning on him.—A noise without of chains falling. JULIA starts.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Be not alarmed. These noises, Julia, we shall be accustom'd to.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I hope not, my father. It is the hour I promised to be at the prison gate. (Faulkner shakes his head) The gentleman seemed a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
And, perhaps, is called so. Ah, girl, the tickery of this knavish world makes a wide difference between honour to woman and to man. The wretch that robs the father of his child, let him but at a gaming table keep his word with man, and he's of honour
Nay, shou'd this wretch, in aggravation, meet that wrong'd father in the field, and lay him at his feet a corpse, then, who dare deny that he's a man of honour?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But he's a merchant, sir—a rank of men whose nobleness and benevolence are far above my praise.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: True; let me not by vague suspicion wrong a worthy man. Go then, my child, but only to the gate; and mark, return with speed.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Shall I not fly, when 'tis to bring a father happiness?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And should it not be so, oh Faulkner, what horrors will be thine! when, in addition to thy wounded pride, thou hearest thy child ask thee for bread thou can'st not give her, see'st her pine daily at thy feet and perish; or, what is worse, should the agony which rends this heart, draw on thee a speedier dissolution, and she be left behind, exposed to want, to villany—that shall be prevented! yet I'll cling to hope—perhaps all may be well again— (Julia screams without) ah! she shrieks! It is my Julia's voice. Villain, forbear! hear a father's cries, or take a father's curse. Blast him, heaven, with thy hottest vengeance! all, all is hushed—she's gone! my child is lost, is dishonoured—dishonoured! no, I wrong her—my girl will die— (a noise again) It approaches—be faithful, eyes!
sp.stage: Enter JAILER and TANGENT, he bearing JULIA in his arms.
sp.p: My Julia! oh give her to my arms!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, after what has passed, some excuse is due for this intrusion. There, sir, is my apology.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: She revives!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Where am I? my father! my deliverer!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Aye, that he is—As this gentleman was coming to jail—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Hush! (stopping his mouth) Passing this place, sir, I heard a woman shriek, and saw some villains hurry this lady into a chaise—

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Then he bravely flew among them, and laid about him, and—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The conquest was easy, for the rascals fled.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Saved by the man I've so deeply wrong'd! His presence tortures me. Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, a word in private.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah! am I detected?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I've been with your attorney, sir.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Racks! tortures!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And have discovered an infernal act of villany.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Well then, it is discovered.—Madness! fiends! I wou'd be alone.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You mistake.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I insist on being alone.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A message from your attorney, sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis well—Captain Faulkner, you will be sorry for this behaviour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
My brain rocks! ah, my child, do I hold
thee in a parent's grasp, pure, unpolluted? Julia, we part no more—never—never! 'tis time to tell thee thy father is a villain.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Impossible! perhaps your too keen sense of honour interprets harshly.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: No, no. E'en now the man I wrong'd gave it its substantial title—an infernal act of villany.—Horrors accumulate.—On one side, dishonour; on the other, famine. Julia! (taking both her hands, and looking on her) tho' dreadful, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Your words and looks terrify me.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: In this world we can cherish no hope of happiness.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But in the next, my father—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: True, girl; then the sooner we are there, the better.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: 'Tis in our power, Julia, to expedite our happiness.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What means my father?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now, heart-strings, hold awhile! collect the exalted resolution of thy soul, and mark. Out of the wreck of fortune, I have preserved something, my child, to free us from poverty, from dishonour, and to give us everlasting peace.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Blest tidings!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Behold!
sp.stage: (taking from each pocket a pistol, and presenting one to Julia.)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Horror!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ha! hast thou not by miracle escaped dishonour? and is not thus to live, to meet perdition?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is not thus to die, to meet perdition?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: It is too late for thought. Here—Ah, dost thou shirk?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Suicide! my soul sickens at the thought.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Then live, base girl, and see thy father die. Live till scorn shall point at thee, and, mocking, cry, behold the violated daughter of the villain Faulkner!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: There's madness in the thought—give me the deathful instrument.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Hold! oh let me kiss thee— (a knocking at the door) we're interrupted— (knocking repeated) go to the door
sp.stage: (Julia goes to the door, returns with a letter, opens it, shrieks, and runs into her father's arms.)
sp.p: What means this frantic joy? bank notes! a letter! ah, from Tangent— (reads) While I intreat you will do me the honour of employing these notes, it gives me great pleasure to inclose you a letter, which at once exposes the villany of your agents, and restores you to prosperity and happiness— (looks over the letter, then falls on his knee) omnipotent providence! humbled with the dust, behold a repentant wretch! but thou art slow to punish, and thy mercies are infinite. Here, too, let me ask pardon—my child! —But where is thy deliverer, the preserver of thy honour, thy life? Within—Has Mr. Tangent left the prison?

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Oh, no, sir.—Then they don't know that he's a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Then fly to him, my child. He is the legitimate son of honour, I the base born slave of pride. Bring him to me, that I may kneel and bless him.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father—I'm dizzy with my happiness. One kiss of rapture, and I am gone.

div3.head: SCENE III.
div3.stage: Enter JAILER, followed by TANGENT, (fetter'd) a Solicitor and Undertaker.

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Oh, how they become him! I'm sure your leg was made for them. I'll be hanged if I flatter you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Indeed you do not. Certainly, a very neat appendage to a gentleman—heigho!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: I declare it gives me pleasure to see you in them.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You have all the pleasure to yourself. Heigho! I feel devilish queer. Retire!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: A card from the gentlemen of our club.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your club! (reads) The gentlemen prisoners inform Mr. Tangent they have elected him a member of the select club, and solicit the honour of his company to a turbot, haunch, claret, and chicken hazard.—The club, to prevent accidents, meet on Sunday, Monday being hanging-day. Hanging-day!—'tis alarming, very,—what do you want?—

sp.speaker: Solicitor.
sp.p: I'm a Newgate solicitor; and for 501. will undertake to prevent gibbeting at least.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Gibbeting! Begone, you croaking— (drives, him off) And what will you undertake?

sp.speaker: Undertaker.
sp.p: Sir, I'm an undertaker; and if you, are not engaged, wou'd be proud to inter—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Go to the devil! (drives him off) Leave the room, you infernal—Gibbet! Undertaker!—Heigho! —Pugh! I can't have kill'd the fellow—his scull must have been thinner than mine, to crack with such a paltry blow.—How has my letter sped with Faulkner —That's nearest my heart—Oh, Julia!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: You'll find Mr. Tangent in the next room, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Heavens! 'tis Julia! 'tis herself! and joy brightens her lovely countenance. Oh, let me meet her! Damn these things! 'Sdeath! how shall I conceal my disgrace? What can I do to—

div3.stage: (Tangent holds his handkerchief before his fetters).

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, with a heart oppress'd with gratitude, let me kneel—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Loveliest creature, rise! Allow me to— (is about to raise her when he recollects his fetters) Pray rise, ma'am; you distress me.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Why should benevolence shrink from praise?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Angelic excellence! call it love, adoration— I'm your slave—upon my soul, I'm in chains—I beg pardon—but my love is pure as your own thoughts.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Sir, I believe you noble—above base concealment.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: By heaven I would not conceal any thing; that is, not any thing that—that—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, my father is anxious to see you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Happy tidings!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Will you favour him with your company?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Instantly.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: This way then.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am. (recollecting himself) That is, presently—I'll come presently to—to—to his house.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Farewel! Oh, sir, my feelings wou'd be unworthy, cou'd I express them—But these tears of joy—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Dry them, lovely creature. By heaven, they affect me to that—
sp.stage: (raises his handkerchief to his eyes, recollects himself, then pulls a chair towards him, and gets behind it, leans over it, and wipes his eyes.)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What noise was that?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I did not hear any noise.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: The clank of fetters. I dread to meet those miserable beings—Perhaps some horrid murderer.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Very likely, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yet I must pity them.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis very kind of you, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Poor wretches!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, poor devils!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Farewel, sir. We shall see you soon.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
I'II follow you and fly—Egad, that's the only way I can follow. Heigho! But away with
melancholy. Julia Faulkner is happy; and can I be otherwise?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: There he sits, the picture of despair, poor fellow! This lesson has cured him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: These decorations are not exactly the thing, to be sure, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: How mournfully he looks down on his disgraceful fetters!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Julia is happy—The thought is extacy!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: How lucky that I came! His despair might have made him kill himself.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I could sing—dance for joy. Dance! I remember seeing a man at the playhouse dance a hornpipe in a pair of these things, and did it devilish well too—Let me see—somehow!—Tol de rol lol lol! (sings and dances, not seeing Caustic) My uncle! Confusion!

sp.speaker: Caustic.
sp.p: I shall go mad! (after a struggle for breath) Oh you—I can't speak—dancing! But you'll have but one dance more, and that will be upon nothing, —you—the wounded man is dead.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Dead! Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Most certain, sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Am I then a murderer? Shall I never see Julia Faulkner more?

div3.stage: Enter NED (with a patch on his forehead) and JAILER.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Sir, I must go home;—so, will thank you for the five guineas you promised.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Go along, you scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Never to behold—Eh! (seeing Ned) Oh, my dear fellow, how glad I am to see you! (embraces him) Here, take off these things, will you? (Ned and Jailer take off the fetters) I thought such a head as this cou'd not be easily crack'd, ha, ha, ha! (exulting) Now to my Julia! Farewel, uncle! Here's cash for you both.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Then I must kill the dog myself. (grasps his cane) Nephew, come here—will you only listen to me?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I'll listen to you for a month.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I'll murder him—stop that villain.

div3.head: SCENE I.
div3.stage: Enter DASHALL with an opened letter.

sp.speaker: Dashall.
sp.p: Now this is not fair play! What a rascally shame! What the devil does Fortune mean by it? Zounds! to be bankrupt! My name in the Gazette at this moment, when I was doing them all in such a capital style! And, then, to lose the nice girl! I suppose I shall have that fellow, Tangent, demanding satisfaction. Oh, my smashing will fly about like wildfire. If I can't in one hour humbug old Allspice, and marry his daughter, I must scud. Fortune, be but kind! Damn her! she's a jade, I'll not invoke her. But thou, genius of swindling! Oh stick by me now, and I'll never forsake thee. She's propitious! for here comes one flat.
Well, Toby, what are you thinking about?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p:
London. I never was there. You must show me the sights—The lions at the Tower, and the bulls and bears at the Stock Exchange; the parliament-house, and the wax-work;—the bench of bishops, and
the maids of honour. And, my dear friend, you'll show me the King's Bench?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, that I will.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: And, I say, the pretty girls.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: True, my dear fellow: but about the trifle of money—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Trifle! Oh, the half-crown that I lost to you at all-fours.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, no; the five thousand.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh dear, that's an enormous sum.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: My letters from Petersburgh say, the frost has set in there so devilish hard, that furs will be any price.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Indeed! I have the money in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Have you? Give it me directly.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Friendly creature, how anxious you are!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I am. Upon my soul, I feel just as if I were going to receive it for my own advantage.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Good soul! Well, here it is.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Now I touch.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, sir, wishes to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Very well. I'll come to him.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Confound Mr. Caustic! My bankruptcy will be blown, and then—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Tho' 'tis for my own advantage, I can't bear to part with my dear notes.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: If I have not the money directly, 'tis all up, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: That would be a pity.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: It wou'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Why, then, there they are—but let me take leave of them—my pretty ones, good bye to you; and be sure now you come again, with each of you a companion. One hug, and then we part.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Now I touch to a certainty.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Now hold our hand.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: The Gazette, sir.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh the devil!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Stop!
sp.stage: (returns the notes again to his pocket)

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Never mind the Gazette.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: We'll just take a peep at the bankrupts.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Here's luck again!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Ah! (taking out his glasses) Here they are.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But don't you see there's great news. The following dispatch was this day received by—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: We'll read that afterwards.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: "Whereas a commission of—"

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Why, friend Toby, ha, ha, ha!
sp.stage: (taking hold of the arm that holds the Gazette)

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: What's the matter?—"Whereas a—"

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ha, ha! What the devil! 'Tis all up with you—can't you see without spectacles? Ha, ha! Oh, then you are dished with the girls, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p:
See without them? to be sure I can—just as
well without them, as with them. Bless your soul! I only use them, because they are knowing.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, knowing enough for young men with remarkable strong eyes; but—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: "Whereas—"

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: And then such a quiz of a pair as these! How you wou'd be hoaxed! Now, only see what a gig I look in them.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: First we'll just look at the bankrupts— "Whereas—"

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, no—now see. (takes the glasses and Gazette from Allspice, lets fall the glasses, and in pretending to pick them up, treads on them, and breaks them) Zounds! I've broke them.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: 'Tis of no consequence—they were of no use to me—Thank heaven, I don't want them.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But I beg ten thousand pardons. I believe you wished to look over the list of bankrupts—there they begin, you see.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh yes, I see.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Any body there particular? Any body there you know?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, no, no—a few reptiles of retailers, but none of your fine dashers like us—Ah! they manage their matters too cleverly to let me see them here.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To be sure they do. (takes the Gazette) There I am, sure enough—what an escape! Well, now the notes—now I touch, or the devil's in't!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes, here they are. (takes notes out again) Stop—one—two—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Three—four—five. Just the sum.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh dear. I don't like to part with them! My dear friend, I'm afraid I've given you a thousand short—Let me look at them again, will you?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Certainly. No—exactly the sum.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, sir, is in a great hurry and in a great passion, and wants to speak to you about miss Clementina, and that gentleman's marriage.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ha, ha! here's capital luck! Go to him, my dear Toby—let it take place directly. Tell him my affairs are desperate,—my love affairs, I mean.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Well, I will — I'll say you're a bankrupt in hope. But don't send away all the money to London at once, pray don't.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Certainly not—depend on't, if I can help it, I'll not part with a farthing of it.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, thank you—'Tis an enormous sum—I don't know what to think.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What to think! Think of the profits. Nay, why so dull? Where's your spirits, your life?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: My life! You've got it in your pocket, so pray take care of it; for, indeed, the loss of it wou'd kill me.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Here they are! Oh, there goes lady Sorrel in a fury. I think she looks as if she were in the Gazette— I must be after her—Well, I've done the old one, however. Bravo, my boy, Dashall! All I say is, you've justified the opinion I always had of you.

div3.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: How provoking! I cou'd cry for vexation. Where is that fellow, Dashall, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: So, sir, you've managed matters finely!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I rather think I have.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Provoking! to have that gypsey, that Julia Faulkner in your power, and then to lose her!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I could not help it.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I believe you could not help running away.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nonsense! Will your talking recover her?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Yes, if you'll attend to it. I have a plan, if you are not afraid of her—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Dam'me! Do you think I'm afraid of a woman?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: That villain, Tangent, has released her father from prison: but I've a scheme—stay, he's here.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Then I would rather not stay; He's a desperate fighting fellow! (aside) I say, step in here till he passes.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: What! running away again?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p:
'Sdeath! no. But my affairs are devilish ticklish. I have not time to quarrel and kill people.
Here he comes: If you don't go in, I'll give up Julia. Can't you tell me your plan there as well as here?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: But if we should be seen,—and my cousin Caustic hear I was shut up with a man, I shou'd be ruined.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pshaw! Nobody wants to ruin you. Zounds! only while he passes.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
That infernal hornpipe has completely ruin'd me with my uncle. But, be that as it may, if she will consent, Julia Faulkner shall be mine, tho' this spade were my only portion. And why not this spade? What can more nobly employ the exertion of man than improving the blessings providence has sent him? I can fancy myself seated at my cottage-fire, with my Julia and thirteen children,—the equal serenity of the scene harmonizing with the tranquil uniformity of my disposition. Happy employment! There we see the art of man even giving climate. (pointing to the hot-house) Eh! I thought I caught a glimpse of that hypocrite, lady Sorrel, endeavouring to conceal herself. I suppose a hot-house suits the warmth of her disposition; if so, she shall have it hot enough.— (aloud) Confound the carelessness of these rascally gardeners, leaving doors and windows open!—cold as an ice-house. (locks door) The grapes will be sour; and I know there's a fine old sensitive plant within, that can't bear being exposed—I'll bring things forward, (during this he puts up the glass, opens the flues, and blows the fire) Zounds! My
uncle, and as furious as when I left him!—I must be off—I presume your ladyship begins to feel rather warm and comfortable.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Come, sir, dispatch—Let me get rid of this business. Where's this Dashall and your daughter? I must be gone—I would not stay in this infernal town—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: True; there's no making a splash here. I must reside in a place suited to my elegant ideas. London's the shop for me.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: But, zounds! where's your daughter?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: How kind of you to regard my Cleme!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I regard her! Sir, she's a lady I particularly dislike. Do you think I give her thirty thousand pounds because—No, sir, I do it to revenge myself on that thoughtless, profligate, tormenting nephew, that has teized, has made me mad—but where is she?—Oh, she comes—heyday! what, in tears?

div3.stage: Enter CLEMENTINA, weeping, holding a Gazette in her hand; and Officer.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: What's the matter, Cleme?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Now this is extremely disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: What makes my dear daughter unhappy? Nothing serious, I hope. None of the spoons lost, eh?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Spoons? Don't talk to me of spoons. My fortune is lost, my husband is lost—this man is come to take him away. Mr. Dashall is a bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: His name in the Gazette.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Where? where? Oh, will any body lend me a pair of spectacles?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Are you short-sighted?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh very—I've a notion.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Ah! (pointing to his name in the Gazette) There he is.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Where is he? (jumping round and seizing Caustic) He's a villain!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I thought he was your friend,—the man that cropt you.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes, he has cropp'd me with the devil to it; cropped me of five thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Five thousand pounds! What was he to do with it?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: To buy tippets.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Tippets!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Ay, and bosom-friends. What had I to do with bosom-friends? Damn all friends! I was once happy and friendless. Eh! I left him here. I hope he is not gone to make a splash with my dear money—I hope he's in the garden. Mr. Dashall! Mr. Dashall! I want to speak to you, Mr. Dashall. Come here, will you, my dear friend? I only want to speak to you. Oh, if I cou'd but fasten on him—I want to give you another thousand pounds. I do indeed. Oh, the infernal villain! My excellent friend, don't hide yourself.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Everlasting, everlasting disappointment! will nobody have thirty thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, pray sir, don't be in such a hurry. If you will but have the kindness to wait till to-morrow, I dare say I can get somebody to marry me.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I would not stay an hour. Will nobody have thirty thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: I will, give it to me.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: But on the terms—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Any terms.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Will you marry?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Any body.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You marry, pa! too ridiculous, a vast deal.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, hussey—I feel I shall be miserable without money, so I may as well marry and be miserable with it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Caustic, only wait till to-morrow. I'll ask every body to have me. Oh do! lud, I shall be under such a style of obligation.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I'll make it a principle to please. Oh do!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Won't you? then you are an old wretch, a brute; and I hope, pa, if you marry, you'll be a brute: and (to Caustic) I vow I wish your gout may return, and shoot up into your wither'd head in such a style— Yes, you may laugh— (sobbing) but to be utterly ruined is extremely disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Oh, he's gone!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
Friend Toby, a lucky thought—I've hit
upon a wife for you. What say you to your visitor, my cousin, Lady Sorrel? she's virtuous.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: I've my doubts.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Oh fie! no, she's extremely correct,—correct even to appearances. Her good conduct defies suspicion.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Then 'tis a bargain.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: With all my heart; and by giving you my hand, I give
sp.stage: (going to shake hands, a crash is heard in the hot-house.)
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: More of my property going. I suppose some old blind tabby cat has got into my hot-house. Bring the blunderbuss, will you?
sp.stage: (to officer)—(Lady Sorrel screams, and Allspice unlocks the door, and Lady Sorrel comes out.)

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Lady Sorrel!

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Hey day, cousin!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I'm quite faint.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Rest on me, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: The heat of the place.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: You seem rather warm. Pray, have you seen any thing of my dear friend, Mr. Dashall?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I, sir? no.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: This has an odd appearance.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I'll explain it. Cousin, I went in to pull a bunch of grapes; and a booby of a servant passing by, lock'd the door.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
I'm satisfied. Well, cousin, I've got you a
husband here. Nay, no blushing. You are too wise and too old for girlish affectation. With my friend Toby, I give you thirty thousand pounds, and as times go, a pretty honest man.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Yes, my lady, an honest pretty man.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: And, friend Toby, with my cousin you have neither youth nor beauty, to be sure; but abundance of chastity, virtue, and benevolence, so heaven—

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Zounds! what's that? I dare say, one of Cleme's puppy dogs.— (to officer) Go in, and pull him out by the cuff of the neck

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I declare I'm quite faint again.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Let me support you—I'll never leave you.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Have I found yon at last?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Mr. Dashall!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Who?
sp.stage: (Lets go Lady Sorrel, and runs to Dashall, puts his hand into his pocket, and recovers his notes.)
sp.p: Give me my money, you villain! here it is. Oh, let me kiss you, and lay you to my faithful breast.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: How have I been deceived!

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Mr. Caustic, you'll excuse my marrying.— (to Dashall) I can see your roguery without spectacles, you monopolizer of viliany! farewell to dashing! Roger, bring me my wig and apron.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I entreat—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: My nephew! dare he come in my presence? then you shall see me knock him down.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: No, no

div3.stage: Enter TANGENT, followed by FAULKNER and JULIA.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: In vain you fly me.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You distress me—I beg, sir,—I insist—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Never can my soul be satisfied, till my knees bend in gratitude—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner! upon my soul, 'tis devilish hard to have one's feelings distressed, because a man has done a trifling act—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: A trifling act! have you not redeemed me from prison, from despair? have you not preserved my Julia's honour?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Stand by. I don't think I shall knock him down.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: If I have been so fortunate, let my reward be the preservation of that honour with my life, and for my life.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Sir, I shou'd certainly feel proud of your alliance;—but you have a relation.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: What, old uncle, ha, ha! I have certainly plagued him most confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I believe I'll knock him down

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: But, upon my honour, to make him unhappy, wou'd give me serious sorrow. (Caustic drops his cane) Oh, sir, give me but Julia Faulkner without fortune—

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: I forbid the banns.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I insist.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p:
And, sir, I insist that you don't marry miss
Faulkner without a fortune, but that you marry her with thirty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Most excellent uncle! my sweetest Julia! and will you, sir, forgive my follies?

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: Heartily, my boy. Frank, I can pardon the head for wandering, when I find the heart's at home.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Tangent, I give you joy.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Gently! while you were affluent, the elegant flavour of your Tokay kept down the coarse twang of the borachio in your manners. But now you're poor, you'll be cut even by your brother swindlers.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Is not this the wretch—?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir, I shou'd be happy to give you satisfaction; but you see I'm in custody— (Faulkner going up to him) Officer, do your duty: why don't you secure me? I never despair—do you think this is the first time I've been in the Gazette? I've some irons in the fire yet.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And if you want more irons, I cou'd recommend you to a pair that wou'd suit you exactly.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Mr. Dashall, are you going to town?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: You may depend upon it, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: If you'll give me leave, I'll accompany you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: First let me thank you, madam, for the delicate anxiety you have shewn respecting me and this gentleman, and for your humanity in arresting my father.

sp.speaker: Caustic.
sp.p: Did she do that? abandoned hypocrite! leave my sight.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p:
Well, I bear no malice. Good bye to you all.
I say, Toby, won't you send some almonds and raisins to Harriet?—ha, ha! Now to London, and my creditors, where I'll nobly give them fivepence halfpenny in the pound, and the jolliest dinner the London Tavern can produce—Good bye to you, gigs! dam'me, I'll make a splash yet.
sp.stage: Exeunt Dashall, Lady Sorrel, and Officer.

sp.speaker: Allsp.
sp.p: Put him in my horse-pond. Let him make a splash there.

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: Pray, is Lady Sorrel—oh the devil—

sp.speaker: "Faulk.
sp.p: Hold—oh dread not my personal chastisement: your abject villainy protects you from that—

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: It is not the first time it has stood my friend.

sp.speaker: "Faulk.
sp.p: Do you see this letter?

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: I certainly missed it, and am ready to refund.

sp.speaker: "Faulk.
sp.p: You disgrace an honourable profession, and are the vile exception to the liberal and noble character of your nation.

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: Sir! I am worth twenty thousand pounds, and am your humble servant.

sp.speaker: "Tang.
sp.p: Villain!

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p:
Take care what you say, young gentleman—don't you libel an attorney—'tis the most heinous crime—the devil a lawyer will plead your cause for you; but the whole battalion of the black badgers will open upon you, and tell you that libelling an attorney strikes at the root of humanity; it
tears out the vitals existence; it shivers the adamantine bands of society; it makes curds and whey of the milk of human kindness; it convulses and confuses, and disturbs and distorts—Oh! whatever you do, never libel an attorney.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I hope, sir, my Julia has made you a convert.

sp.speaker: Caust.
sp.p: She has indeed—and I beg pardon of her sex, to whom she this given this lesson—that the affection and duty of a daughter is the best security for happiness in a wife; and that filial affection and feminine diffidence is THE WAY TO GET MARRIED. As for you, nephew—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I've bade adieu to all my air-drawn fancies, except the woolsack, in which whim I will once more indulge, in the trembling hope, that our endeavours this night to please, have been crowned with your candid approbation. As many as are content say "Aye." — non-contents, "No." We flatter ourselves the contents have it.

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.byline: Written by Captain TOPHAM. Spoken by Mrs. MATTOCKS.

sp.l: THE dubious title of our Play this night
Might fill mama with joy, or miss with fright.
"The Way to get a Husband," and what not;—
But are they worth the getting when they're got?
"Yes," cries bold miss,—whom mother's kind regard
Has led, at young fourteen, to cock her card,
"Yes," cries bold miss, "whate'er the formals say,
They are worth getting, and I know the way.
—The way's up Bond-street! where we daily range,
Where sauntering bloods crowd Fashion's full exchange!
There (charming scene!) as undismay'd we strut—
Dogs, misses, dukes, and draymen, meet full butt!
There, lounging arm in arm, half-booted crops,
With heads so dark, you'd swear they were—black mops!
There, muslin petticoats with mud so lac'd▪
Here scarlet spencers with an inch of waist,
So scarlet all, my rouge they seem to scoff,
And look like lobsters with their tails cut off!
Here for a husband is the scene to dash,
Here for a town-bred miss to—make a splash.
The plump, brisk widow takes a different road,
She cannot walk down Bond-street:—she's a load!
Good sixteen stone to carry—but yet strong:
She rolls a wool-pack Venus,—broad as long!
Yet she's a tender passion for the stage!
With her, dear private acting is the rage.
